There shouldn't be a problem overriding assert, however...

I think it would be better style to create a helper function to perform
the comparison and return a boolean.  Then use 
  assertTrue("...",myFunction(obj,xml)) 
in your tests.  
This way your custom test code is still enclosed in the test class (or
at least in the same package) and you don't have to override anything in
the testing framework.

If you were comparing two objects of the same class, I would recomend
just putting the comparison code in the .equals() method, but it sounds
like you are comparing an object to an XML fragment.

On Tue, 2002-02-12 at 20:31, pisharath_k wrote:
    I have a basic question. I have a set of classes whose values are set 
    from a file by a Reader object. Now I want to test whether these 
    values are set correctly. I can use preset values for testing 
    purpose. But due to the large number and complexity of these classes 
    it would be very difficult and cumbersome to create objects with 
    these preset values manually for testing against the ones created by 
    the Reader.
    
    I am thinking of creating a helper class for each of the above 
    classes. I will pass it the object to compare, and it will compare 
    the object's data against pre-defined values that will be stored in 
    the helper classes. I will need to extend junit's Assert class for 
    these helper class, since they will assert if there is a data 
    mismatch. So my question is,  is it okay to extend Assert in my own 
    classes ? Has anyone faced this problem before, and if so how did you 
    solve this ? Any help will be appreciated.
    
    Thanks,
    - krishnan
